content.text: Fig. 1.2 shows a cross-section through the cone and the steel ball
On Fig. 1.2, draw labelled arrows to show the two forces acting on the ball
Describe how the forces acting on the ball cause its acceleration to be centripetal
The ball moves in a circle of radius \(0.15 \text{m}\)
Show that the speed of the ball is \(1.4 \text{m} \text{s}^{-1}\)
Calculate the angular speed \(\omega\) of the ball
The speed of the ball is increased
Explain why the radius of the circular path of the ball increases
[Total: 9]
A steel ball is placed on the inside surface of a hollow circular cone. The ball moves in a horizontal circle at constant speed, as shown in Fig. 1.1
The angle of the side of the cone to the horizontal is \(52^{\circ}\). There is no friction between the ball and the cone
The magnitude of the gravitational potential on the surface of a planet of radius \(R\) is \(\phi\). The planet can be considered to be an isolated sphere
On Fig. 2.1, sketch the variation of the gravitational potential with distance \(x\) from the centre of the planet for values of \(x\) between \(R\) and \(4R\)
A satellite is in a geostationary orbit above the Earth. At time \(t = 0\) , the magnitude of the gravitational potential due to the Earth at the location of the satellite is \(\phi\)
On Fig. 2.2, sketch the variation of the gravitational potential due to the Earth at the location of the satellite for values of \(t\) between \(t = 0\) and \(t = 24\) hours
The electric potential difference (p.d.) between two parallel plates is \(V,\) as shown in Fig. 2.3
The distance between the plates is \(d\). The region between the plates is a vacuum
On Fig. 2.4, sketch the variation of the electric potential with distance from the positive plate
Fig. 2.4
[Total: 7]
P and Q are in thermal equilibrium
State what is meant by the term thermal equilibrium
Data for P and Q are given in Table 3.1
P and Q are initially both at the same temperature
P is supplied with \(24 \text{kJ}\) of thermal energy. After some time, P and Q are once again both at the same temperature as each other
P and Q are perfectly insulated from the surroundings
Determine the change in temperature \(\Delta T\) of Q
Two metal cuboids P and Q are in thermal contact with each other
The temperature of the nitrogen gas is increased from \(0^\circ \text{C}\) to \(210^\circ \text{C}\)
Determine the work done on the gas
work done = .........J
Determine the number \(N\) of molecules of nitrogen gas
The mass of a nitrogen molecule is \(4.7 \times 10^{-26} \text{kg}\)
Calculate the root-mean-square (r.m.s.) speed of a nitrogen molecule at \(210\,^\circ \text{C}\)
[Total: 12]
Nitrogen may be assumed to be an ideal gas. A fixed amount of nitrogen gas is contained at a constant pressure of \(1.6 \times 10^5 \text{Pa}\)
The variation of the volume \(V\) of the gas with the temperature \(\theta\) of the gas is shown in Fig. 3.1
Show that the angular frequency of the vibration of the surface is \(4.2 \times 10^{7} \text{rad} \text{s}^{-1}\)
Determine the maximum acceleration \(a_0\) of the vibration of the surface
The crystal may be modelled as a single mass of \(2.4 \times 10^{-4} \text{kg}\) that vibrates as shown in Fig. 4.1
Calculate the total energy \(E\) of the vibrations
The crystal is made from piezoelectric material
Explain how the crystal is made to vibrate
A parallel beam of ultrasound waves is incident on a muscle-bone boundary. Data for muscle and bone are given in Table 4.1
Calculate the percentage of the intensity of the ultrasound beam that is transmitted at this boundary
percentage transmitted = .........%
[Total: 12]
The crystal generates ultrasound waves that are used to obtain diagnostic information about internal structures

A small crystal is made to vibrate with simple harmonic motion. The variation with time \(t\) of the displacement \(x\) of one surface of the crystal from its equilibrium position is shown in Fig. 4.1
A capacitor of capacitance \(C_{1}\) is connected in series with a second capacitor of capacitance \(C_{2}\)
Show that the combined capacitance \(C\) of the two capacitors is given by
Three identical capacitors, each of capacitance \(C\) , are connected in a network as shown in Fig. 5.1
The variation of the charge \(Q\) with the potential difference (p.d.) \(V\) between the terminals X and Y is shown in Fig. 5.2
Determine the time constant \(\tau\) of the circuit. Give a unit with your answer
Determine the time taken for the discharge current to reduce to \(15\%\) of the initial discharge current
The capacitor network in Fig. 5.1 is charged and then connected to a resistor of resistance \(54 \text{k}\Omega\). The capacitor network discharges through the resistor
The potential difference (p.d.) between the plates of the velocity selector is \(V.\) The separation of the plates is \(d\) and the magnetic flux density is \(B.\)
Show that the speed \(u\) of ions that pass undeviated through the velocity selector is given by

Positive ions with kinetic energy \(4.1 \times 10^{-17} \text{J}\) and mass \(3.2 \times 10^{-27} \text{kg}\) pass undeviated through the velocity selector when \(V\) is equal to \(980 \text{V}\) and \(d\) is equal to \(3.6 \times 10^{-2} \text{m}\)
Determine \(B.\)
A proton passes undeviated through the velocity selector
An alpha particle enters the velocity selector at the same speed as the proton
State how the expression in (a) predicts that the alpha particle also passes undeviated through the velocity selector
By reference to Fig. 6.1 and to the forces acting on a positive ion, determine the direction of the magnetic field. Explain your reasoning
The positive ions in (b) enter the velocity selector with greater kinetic energy
On Fig. 6.1, sketch the path of these ions
[Total: 11]

An electric field and a magnetic field are used to form a velocity selector. Charged particles, called ions, pass into a region of uniform electric and magnetic fields that is between parallel plates, as shown in Fig. 6.1
State Faraday's law of electromagnetic induction
Explain how Fig. 7.2 shows that \(E\) is proportional to the velocity \(v\) of the rod
Use Faraday's law to show that the variation of \(E\) with time \(t\) is given by
where \(a\) is the acceleration of the rod
The length of the rod is \(0.45 \text{m}\). The acceleration \(a\) of the rod is \(7.8 \text{m} \text{s}^{-2}\)
Determine the value of \(B\)
[Total: 9]
A metal rod is accelerated uniformly from rest in a uniform magnetic field as shown in Fig. 7.1
The rod has length \(l\) and the flux density of the magnetic field is \(B\)
An electromotive force (e.m.f.) is induced in the rod. The variation with time \(t\) of the induced e.m.f. \(E\) is shown in Fig. 7.2
State what is meant by a photon
Calculate the wavelength of the light
wavelength = .........m
The power of the beam emitted by the laser is \(1.0 \times 10^{-2} \text{W}\)
Calculate the number of photons emitted per unit time by the laser
number per unit time = .........s\(^{-1}\)
The photons are incident normally on a surface. Half of the number of photons are absorbed by the surface, and half are reflected
Determine the average force exerted by the beam of photons on the surface
average force = .........N

A laser emits red light of a single wavelength. The light is produced when electrons move from a higher energy level to a lower energy level. The difference in energy between the two levels is \(1.96 \text{eV}\)
random
spontaneous
Radioactive decay is both random and spontaneous
State what is meant by:
Define half-life
Data for the binding energy per nucleon of the particles involved in the decay of a nucleus of polonium-193 are given in Table 9.1
Determine the energy, in eV, released when a nucleus of polonium-193 decays into a nucleus of lead-189
energy = .........eV
State the name of the quantity that is represented by the magnitude of the gradient of the line in Fig. 9.1
Use Fig. 9.1 to determine the half-life, in ms, of polonium-193
A pure sample of polonium-193 contains \(N_0\) nuclei. After a time \(t\) the sample contains \(N\) nuclei of polonium-193. The variation of \(\ln (N / N_0)\) with \(t\) is shown in Fig. 9.1
State what happens to the positrons emitted by the tracer
Explain why a tracer with a half-life of approximately 2 hours is a suitable tracer to use
Positron emission tomography (PET scanning) uses a radioactive tracer
Polonium-193 ( \(^{193}_{84}\mathrm {Po})\) is an unstable nuclide. A nucleus of polonium-193 decays to a nucleus of lead-189 ( \(^{189}_{82}\mathrm {Pb})\) by emitting an alpha-particle
State what is meant by the luminosity of a star
Explain how standard candles are used to determine the distance to a galaxy
The Sun rotates with a period of \(2.07 \times 10^6 \text{s}\)
Show that the radius of the Sun is \(6.93 \times 10^8 \text{m}\)
State and explain how the expected wavelength of the light observed from Z compares with the emitted wavelength
The luminosity of the Sun is \(3.8 \times 10^{26} \text{W}\)
Use the information in (b)(i) to calculate the surface temperature of the Sun
temperature = .........K
[Total: 11]
The Sun rotates on its axis. Points X, Y and Z are on the equator of the Sun as shown in Fig. 10.1
The wavelengths of light from points X and Y are observed and recorded in Table 10.1
